node.title: Albanese says Omicron reinforces case for purpose-built quarantine over hotels
node.description: The arrival of the new COVID-19 "variant of concern"Â has revived the political debate over quarantine ahead of a national cabinet meeting on Tuesday.
node.content:
["The arrival of the new COVID-19 \"variant of concern\"\u00a0has revived the political debate over quarantine ahead of a national cabinet meeting on Tuesday.", "Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese said a return to hotel quarantine to deal with the arrival of the Omicron variant would show a failure of foresight, telling 7.30 the government should have had more \"purpose-built\" quarantine facilities in place by now.", "Prime Minister Scott Morrison said it was \"too early\" to say if quarantine rules would need to be adjusted but confirmed it would be on the agenda at the upcoming meeting with state and territory leaders.\u00a0", "The Prime Minister has consistently defended the system of hotel quarantine that has underpinned Australia's approach to incoming passengers throughout the pandemic, describing it as \"99.99 per cent effective\".\u00a0", "A number of states have tightened their rules for international arrivals\u00a0in response to the Omicron variant, with some now requiring 72 hours of self-isolation. South Australia, which has been trialling a quarantine-at-home model, has increased its quarantine requirements to 14 days.", "The changes come less than a month after New South Wales removed all quarantine requirements for vaccinated travellers, with Victoria and the ACT following suit.\u00a0", "\u201cThe idea that we would return to hotel quarantine when it's been responsible for more than 20 breaches that have had real consequences for the economy just shows a failure to have that foresight,\" Mr Albanese told 7.30.", "
Parliament's days numbered\u00a0
", "", "
Anthony Albanese says the Morrison government\u00a0\"doesn't have an agenda\".(ABC News: Adam Kennedy)
", "The Morrison government released its proposed dates for parliamentary sittings in 2022 on Monday, sparking new speculation about election timing.\u00a0", "Asked about the hypothetical 2022 budget listed for March 29, Mr Albanese said he suspected the government would do one of two things.", "\"It tells you that they'll either go after Australia Day and not have Parliament sit at all [and have the election on] March 5 or March 12, or they'll have a budget [on March 29] and then go on the following weekend,\" he said.\u00a0", "Mr Albanese said that in either scenario, the limited number of sitting days was indicative of a government \"that doesn't have an agenda\".\u00a0", "", "
What COVID-19 travel insurance doesn't cover you for(Emilia Terzon)
"]
